citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The drug cabinet contained expired medications (dewormers, antibiotics, pain medications, supplements, eye
medications) that were comingled with non-expired medications ready for use. Expired medical products may lose their
effectiveness and may not assists the animals in recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animals without
proper protection against serious and deadly diseases. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Expired medication should be properly disposed of. The licensee must ensure
that all medical products being maintained for use at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the
health and well-being of the animals. Correction date: June 9, 2023.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, record of animals on hand, environmental enhancement program for non-
human primates, and records of acquisition and disposition were not available for review by the inspector. Review of
records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine
compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal
Welfare Act and the regulations are available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correction date: June 9, 2023.

Multiple non- human primate enclosures are in need of repair. In the primary enclosure housing two spider monkeys, two
wooden boards on the interior walls have exposed nails protruding towards the animals. The enclosure housing two
capuchins contain bent, jagged edges on the metal shift gate door. The licensee must ensure structural elements shall be
sound and in good repair, free from hazardous conditions such as sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or
deteriorated materials. Correction date: June 19, 2023.

The outdoor food receptacles for the non-human primates are currently attached to the outside of the sheltered housing
enclosures and are open to the weather elements and to contamination by pests. All food receptacles have an excessive
number of flies in and around them. Contaminated or wet food can cause illness or health problems for the animals and
may prevent them from obtaining necessary nutrition. Food and food receptacles must be located to minimize any risk of
contamination by pests. The facility must ensure there is no molding, deterioration, contamination, or caking or wetting of
food placed in self-feeders. Correction date: June 2, 2023.

The enclosure housing female pigs contain several feeders with deteriorating and damaged wood sections with exposed
rusty nails. Sharp points, particularly those in areas that animals frequently contact, increase the risk of animal injury. The
facility must ensure that enclosures are all structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury. Correction date: June 9, 2023.

The two large pig enclosures and the single enclosure housing 13 water buffalo do not have enough shade structures to
contain all the animals at one time. Outdoor enclosures with inadequate shade may cause overheating or discomfort of
the animals. Sufficient shade by natural or artificial means must be provided to all animals kept outdoors to protect
themselves from direct sunlight. Correction date: July 24, 2023.

Within the cattle enclosures, there are large puddles of water and mud surrounding the hay feeders. These animals must
stand in water and/or thick mud in order to get to their food. Improper drainage within enclosures does not ensure a
clean, dry environment which can lead to health hazards for the animals. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly
eliminate excess water from within the enclosures. Correction date: July 24, 2023

In the zebra enclosure, there are several piles of wood, power tools, and construction debris. According to the facility
representative, the barn located within the enclosure is undergoing renovation. Piles of debris such as this could injure the
animals or harbor insects and vermin. Premises shall be kept clean, free of trash accumulation, and in good repair in
order to protect animals from injury and illness and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in the
regulations. Correction date: June 19, 2023.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST
Ashley Alger n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The drug cabinet contained expired medications (dewormers, antibiotics, pain medications, supplements, eye 
medications) that were comingled with non-expired medications ready for use. Expired medical products may lose their 
effectiveness and may not assists the animals in recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animals without 
proper protection against serious and deadly diseases. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, 
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Expired medication should be properly disposed of. The licensee must ensure 
that all medical products being maintained for use at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the 
health and well-being of the animals. Correction date: June 9, 2023. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, record of animals on hand, environmental enhancement program for non-
human primates, and records of acquisition and disposition were not available for review by the inspector. Review of

3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Multiple non- human primate enclosures are in need of repair. In the primary enclosure housing two spider monkeys, two 
wooden boards on the interior walls have exposed nails protruding towards the animals. The enclosure housing two 
capuchins contain bent, jagged edges on the metal shift gate door. The licensee must ensure structural elements shall be 
sound and in good repair, free from hazardous conditions such as sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or 
deteriorated materials. Correction date:  June 19, 2023. 
3.82(d) 
   
Feeding. 
The outdoor food receptacles for the non-human primates are currently attached to the outside of the sheltered housing 
enclosures and are open to the weather elements and to contamination by pests. All food receptacles have an excessive 
number of flies in and around them. Contaminated or wet food can cause illness or health problems for the animals and

contamination by pests. The facility must ensure there is no molding, deterioration, contamination, or caking or wetting of 
food placed in self-feeders. Correction date: June 2, 2023. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The enclosure housing female pigs contain several feeders with deteriorating and damaged wood sections with exposed 
rusty nails. Sharp points, particularly those in areas that animals frequently contact, increase the risk of animal injury. The 
facility must ensure that enclosures are all structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury. Correction date: June 9, 2023. 
3.127(a)

Facilities, outdoor. 
The two large pig enclosures and the single enclosure housing 13 water buffalo do not have enough shade structures to 
contain all the animals at one time. Outdoor enclosures with inadequate shade may cause overheating or discomfort of 
the animals. Sufficient shade by natural or artificial means must be provided to all animals kept outdoors to protect 
themselves from direct sunlight. Correction date: July 24, 2023. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Within the cattle enclosures, there are large puddles of water and mud surrounding the hay feeders. These animals must 
stand in water and/or thick mud in order to get to their food.  Improper drainage within enclosures does not ensure a 
clean, dry environment which can lead to health hazards for the animals. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly 
eliminate excess water from within the enclosures. Correction date: July 24, 2023 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the zebra enclosure, there are several piles of wood, power tools, and construction debris. According to the facility 
representative, the barn located within the enclosure is undergoing renovation. Piles of debris such as this could injure the 
animals or harbor insects and vermin. Premises shall be kept clean, free of trash accumulation, and in good repair in 
order to protect animals from injury and illness and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in the 
regulations. Correction date: June 19, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST 
Ashley Alger n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
